comments.text:
The whole "cheese eating surrender monkeys" joke has always irritated me. 
After all this was the nation that gave the world Napoleon, Massena, 
Charles Martel, Philip II, Claude de Villars and La Grande Conde. France 
has an exceptional military history and performed well even in modern 
times, defeating guerilla forces in Algeria. I personally believe that it 
is unfair to judge France's military ability on one war, a war in which it 
faced the Wehrmacht. An army that has been described as one of the best in 
history, and it also had to adapt quickly to new tactics. If Germany was 
able to invade the USA in 1940 I wonder how the American military would 
have fared.

comments.text:
+360Nomad You care to actually back that up with some facts rather than 
supposition over what equipment is better? I was with some French Soldiers 
in AFG. Also notice that aside from the FAMAS the French are using the 
American AT-4 and the American M249 SAW? Not to mention some French units 
in AFG have started wearing Multicam (American) like the rest of NATO. The 
US use of the IOTV is limited to select troops - most Infantry units in AFG 
conducting actual dismounted infantry operations carry smaller plate 
carriers which by default will always be less cumbersome than a full 
armored vest. 

Afghanistan is Afghanistan, Mali is Mali. The French Army is not the US 
Army and they really are not comparable in the measure in which you 
describe here. It is apples and oranges - both fruit, but not the same. We 
can circle the world arguing this rifle is better than that rifle but 
frankly opinions are like a--holes, everyone has one and they always stink. 
Every Army in NATO uses the same techniques and tactics - there is nothing 
in this video that is different than how the US would have conducted it (I 
say from experience). They all train together.

comments.text:
I'm not sure about every about every person being able to be trained into a 
good soldier, for example Arabic countries commonly have a very very poor 
success rate in terms of wars, and it's largely to do with cultural 
differences, arabs have a very rigid system of hierarchy that affects the 
junior officer core, and the infantry as a whole, so that higher cultural 
status is seen as more important, which leads to numerous times when it has 
lead to failure of the Arab armies, like how USAF pilots had to babysit and 
chase Iraqi jets to provide easier targets for Saudi Royalty in F15/16s.

If you were able to completely break through any cultural restraints and 
train in a standard Western manner then that might be possibly, such as the 
capability of the Japanese navy and armies in the First Sino-Japanese war 
and the Russo-Japanese war, after going through major modernisation in the 
Meiji period starting in 1868.
comments.author: barkyindustries

comments.text:
+Србин . I think that any idiot can be trained to be a good soldier. The 
military is honestly the best education system in the world. If you need to 
learn something, you'll learn it very quick. The problem is that Malian 
officers are absolutely incompetant. They should be able to control their 
subordinates, and failing that, they should be able to punish their 
subordinates correctly too. That's why the officer gets shot in the middle 
of the street. He did not have the ability and expected officership to 
simply say: "shut the fuck up and do what I tell you to, or I'll have you 
cleaning shit with your own toothbrush for a month." Instead he decided it 
was the perfect moment for an intellectual debate with the equivalent of a 
fancy Private First Class.

It's exactly why the French, British and Irish are out there training them 
and, in the French case, doing the war for them. The Malians do not know 
anything about war. The Tuareg's do. The Jihadi's do. The French do. The 
Malian's do not.

As for using what you described in order to attack the building; a heavy 
assault is both really dangerous and really ineffective against a compound. 
HE rounds, in particular, are essentially worthless. You do not know how 
many enemies are inside, you do not know if they have hostages including 
women and children, you do not know if the RPG rounds will set off further 
explosions, for example on suicide vests etc, and kill everything within a 
half mile radius, you do not have enough RPG rounds to effectively combat a 
building, you do not know if you will need more RPG rounds, for example if 
the Jihadi's decide to use a VBIED, you will not be able to capture any 
Jihadi's, you will not be able to identify civilians from Jihadi's, you 
will risk covering up more explosive devices in rubble, you will risk 
destroying crucial evidence such as attack orders and combat maps... Fact 
is that if you are attacking a building, you need to get into it fast and 
hard. You need to take the enemy out before they are either reinforced or 
make an escape, just like the recent attack in Kenya. And you definitely 
cannot just level the building. That would be a serious amount of economic 
damage, and political too.

Of course, these are all decisions that the Officer needs to make. Not 
making those decisions cost time and almost cost extra lives. That officer 
needs to be relieved of his command before he gets his soldiers killed or 
they mutiny. He almost had them Blue-on-Blue aswell. That's why they need 
better equipment such as radios, body armour and helmets.

The French performed as perfect an assault as was possible. I can only 
imagine the fireteams moving through the building swiftly and clearing 
methodically, wiping out Jihadi's before they could even fire their weapons 
back. I doubt they even fired 60 bullets.
comments.author: Kikara Vaeindon

comments.text:
+Kikara Vaeindon You got the point. But don't you think that even 
considering the simplest form of tactic is wayyy beyond inteligence level 
of these guys? I mean look at them, i bet that even kids know that you 
don't stand in middle of street like that. Malians could do much better, 
even if they were alone, since insurgents were static, fortified in 
abuilding, they had advantage of choosing the direction of attack, so they 
could work them out with couple of HE RPG's, come behind their back and 
slowly clear the building. I mean, if they did anything expect of that what 
they did would be better. As for the French, they did their job well, after 
all you couldn't expect less from profesional army.
Between, nice plan you wrote there, you'd make a hell of a leader ;)
comments.author: Србин  .

comments.text:
+Данијел Томић Well, by equipment, I mean things like frag grenades, smoke 
grenades, radios, short mortars, armour, helmets, and the most important 
piece of equipment a soldier can have: "a bit of fuckin intelligence". 
Personally, the islamists' position should have been surrounded, covered 
with smoke, and then the APC should have been moved into the compound, 
supported by at least two squads. Then they should have cleared the 
buildings with frags. The Malian troops clearly did not have the capacity 
for it. And as for arguing in the middle of the street with your commander? 
The Corporal was correct in what he was saying, but you never question the 
Commanding Officer's decisions unless they are unreasonable. And by 
unreasonable I mean something like "keep going into their sectors of fire, 
they'll run out of ammo eventually!"

Like, you can see that when the French got there, they were supporting 
their vehicles, they were well-equipped, they had better weaponry, they 
flanked through the market place instead of attacking the building head on. 
They maintained composure and were not rolling around the ground and doing 
duck-walks like a bunch of clowns, they were not arguing in the middle of 
the street only for one of them to get shot. The Tuaregs knew their role 
too, they supported the French very well, and you could see that they were 
clearly much more experienced. I dont like that they wore headscarfs 
though, that seemed like a great way to get yourself shot by friendlies.
comments.author: Kikara Vaeindon

comments.text:

anything but wasting ammo.

comments.text:
+Frederik Sørensen +Niko Williams I think the problem is linked to the 
problem with defining western involvement in Africa. For the most part, 
Western involvement in Africa is either Western business, or Western aid. 
You can view both as colonial capitalism, and people will tend to draw 
negative conclusions about Western/ European nations if businesses linked 
to those nations act irresponsibly. That kinda explains why the West is 
damned if it does, and damned if it doesnt. Its also the reason why Europe 
should and does (sort of) take active interest in maintaining the stability 
of Africa. Buuuut successful intervention has happened before. Check 
British intervention in Sierra Leone.

comments.author: Frede Fup

top_comment.text:
Okay, let's be completely honest: I recognize that the Malian army was 
never a *force majeure* in the world, and it's not likely to be one anytime 
in our lifetimes. However, I find that even for an unprofessional military, 
their display in this documentary is probably one of the worst military 
forms of "discipline" which I have ever witnessed.

*Ever*.

I completely pity the French troops which have to deal with them.

Part two is *extremely* graphic, and I do not suggest watching it unless 
you are ready to see the real and full horrors of war in front of your 
face. The results of suicide bombing and dead bodies left overnight, half 
burned, are graphically filmed. But if you can stomach it, it's worth 
bearing witness.

And before anyone shrieks about killing kids: It isn't the French who put 
the kids into battle with guns to shoot at them. If you want to yell at 
anyone for killing kids, yell at morons who support Islamist causes.

Part Two on Vice's site: http://www.vice.com/ground-zero/mali-part-2

And again: I caution you not to watch this on a weak stomach, or if you 
simply cannot bear horrific videos of the real consequences of war.﻿

captions.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

-A year ago, most of the West
saw Mali as a kind of cultural

center of Africa, a place with
celebrated musicians and a
healthy tourist trade.

But that all changed when the
bungled military coup in the

south led to a jihadist
take-over in the north.

Islamist groups like Ansar Dine
and MUJAO imposed a harsh

system of sharia law in northern
cities like Gao and

Timbuktu, banning everything
from booze and cigarettes to
music and dancing.

In January, the Islamists
launched a second offensive,

sending the Malian army running
and forcing France,

Mali's former colonial
ruler, to intervene.

In a matter of days, French
troops had recaptured all of

northern Mali's major towns
from the rebels.

It looked like the quickest,
cleanest, most successful war
of modern times.

But things aren't ever
that simple.

Now the Malians and the French
are facing a vicious

Afghanistan-style war against
pockets of invisible Muslim

insurgents in a fight with
no real end in sight.

This is the story of the battle
for Gao, the biggest
city in northern Mali.

The surrounding countryside is
still jihadist territory.

And though the French control
the city center--
more or less--

everyday, new homemade bombs
are found in the city, each

one powerful enough
to destroy a tank.

The French and their
Malian allies
need to keep Gao secure.

And to do that, they need to
expel the surrounding rebels.

Where do you think
the rebels are?

-At Gao's only hotel, the Malian
troops seemed relaxed,

even though there was clearly
trouble on the horizon.
[GUN FIRE]
-[SPEAKING FOREIGN LANGUAGE]
-[SPEAKING FOREIGN LANGUAGE]

-I jumped in the back of a
Malian pickup truck heading

towards the battle through
deserted streets.

The French were leaving this
battle to the Malians.

But no one knew what
to expect.

The storm of gunfire was coming
from Gao's central

courthouse, the palace
of justice.

Soldiers milled around
aimlessly, preparing for

battle and trying to work
out what was going on.

It was a scene of
utter confusion.
-[SPEAKING FOREIGN LANGUAGE]

-We were taking fire from
multiple locations.

It became clear that there were
more jihadists in town
than anyone had expected.
-[SPEAKING FOREIGN LANGUAGE]

-The major in charge of these
troops thought there were

snipers on top of the building
opposite, so he sent some
soldiers in to check.
-[SPEAKING FOREIGN LANGUAGE]
-[SPEAKING FOREIGN LANGUAGE]

-On the roof, confusion reigned
as friendly fire threw
us to the floor.
-[SPEAKING FOREIGN LANGUAGE]

-The Malians had worked out
that the jihadists weren't

just in the courthouse
but also in the
marketplace on our right.

They sprayed wild bursts of
machine gun fire at them.

The soldiers exchanged
cigarettes while the corporal
worked out what to do.

Then he rang the commanding
officer down below.
-[SPEAKING FOREIGN LANGUAGE]

-The corporal wanted to smash
the wall down with an armored

car and attack the Islamists,
but his commanding officer
wasn't so sure.
-[SPEAKING FOREIGN LANGUAGE]

-The two men stood in the street
arguing about how to
fight the battle.

Neither of them knew the enemy
were about to make the
decision for them.
[GUN FIRE]
-[SPEAKING FOREIGN LANGUAGE]

-The Jeep came to take the
wounded major away.
-[LAUGHING]
-[SPEAKING FOREIGN LANGUAGE]

-Now the corporal
was in charge.

They took the fight
to the Islamists.
-[SPEAKING FOREIGN LANGUAGE]

-We pulled back a bit while the
armored car drove up to
smash down the wall.
-[SPEAKING FOREIGN LANGUAGE]

-No one wants to drive
through a minefield.

The armored car driver reversed
down the road to

consider a more careful
approach.

While the vehicles considered
the next step, the Malian

soldiers laid down a wall
of covering fire.
-[SPEAKING FOREIGN LANGUAGE]

-It was a few hours into
the battle now.

And the soldiers were beginning
to run out of ammo.
-[SPEAKING FOREIGN LANGUAGE]

-The Malians were about to
launch a head-on assault on
the courthouse.
-[SPEAKING FOREIGN LANGUAGE]

-While the jihadists were
outnumbered and outgunned,
they weren't giving up.

The advance faulted under the
enemy's sustained and accurate
riffle fire.
They needed a better plan.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

title: Ground Zero: Mali - Insurgents vs. The Malian Army (Part 1)
